thread.section_title: Financial Review - Business, Finance and Investment News | afr.com
thread.title: ASX sinks in $35 billion sell-off
thread.title_full: ASX sinks in $35 billion sell-off | afr.com

author: Vanessa Desloires
title: ASX sinks in $35 billion sell-off
text:
ASX Rob Homer Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Vanessa Desloires The Australian sharemarket sank on Thursday, shedding $35 billion in value in an abrupt reversal of the previous day's rally as renewed talk of an interest-rate hike in the United States and global growth fears soured the buoyant mood around Asia.
The benchmark S&P/ASX 200 closed down 2.4 per cent or 126.1 points to 5095, while the broader All Ordinaries fell 2.3 per cent to 5116.9.
Wall Street set a poor lead overnight, turning an early rally into a loss, after a disappointing product update from Apple sent its shares plunging along with the broader market.
Meanwhile, stronger jobs data brought into play the potential for the US Federal Reserve to raise interest rates when it meets next week and a stronger US dollar on the back of that.
"Australia is trapped halfway in the emerging market complex," Credit Suisse analyst Damien Boey​ said.
"US dollar strength is not good for any of these [Asian] economies, because they're running de facto pegs against the US dollar," Mr Boey said.
Those concerns centred on emerging market growth, particularly from China , and weaker regional currencies, drawing into question demand for commodities.
"Predictably the miners have been hurt by that, even though iron ore prices haven't done a lot," Mr Boey said.
 Rio Tinto held up relatively well, down just 0.5 per cent to $51.27, while BHP Billiton lost 3 per cent to $23.92.
The energy sector was the hardest hit, down 3.8 per cent despite talks that Oil Search was in potential takeover talks with ExxonMobil, two days after receiving a bid from bigger rival Woodside Petroleum.
LNG Limited fell 13 per cent, Karoon Gas fell 8.5 per cent, Senex fell 6.9 per cent, the day's worst performing stocks.
Sell-offs in the banks weighed heavily on the market. Commonwealth Bank fell 2.1 per cent to $75.13, Westpac Banking Corporation fell 3.3 per cent to $30.76, ANZ Banking Group shed 3.1 per cent to $27.65, and National Australia Bank fell 3.5 per cent to $30.18.
"The banks are actually underperforming the miners, or at least doing just as badly, and this is an interesting dynamic that has been playing out the past few months," Mr Boey said.
The turnaround on the ASX was mirrored around Asia, with all the major bourses, except Korea's, falling.
Fed still on investors' minds The Asian markets were excited by the prospect of fiscal stimulus from Japan on Wednesday, with the Nikkei soaring almost 8 per cent, but the looming themes of US rate rises and slowing regional growth overwhelmed the buoyant mood on Thursday.
"The market had put aside Fed interest rate concerns, but the strong economic data in the US proves the issue is still very much alive," AMP Capital chief economist Shane Oliver said. "That has caused a rethink around Asia today."
"We are still in this fickle period, the underlying issues regarding Chinese growth and what the Fed will do are still driving markets day to day," Dr Oliver said.
The stronger jobs data in the US were second order and usually not closely watched, he added.
"Investor horizons have shrunk back to a very short-term focus."
Better than expected Australian jobs data also confused investors, as federal Treasurer Joe Hockey had prepared the market for the worst, Mr Boey said.
Mr Hockey warned changes to unemployment benefits could skew the numbers substantially higher.
But they came in at 6.2 per cent, "well above downtrodden expectations, and the market didn't know what to do with that", Mr Boey said. A meagre attempt at a rally after the data was released quickly faded.
Defensive stocks were no refuge on Thursday – Woolworths fell 2.2 per cent to $24.76 and Wesfarmers lost 1.8 per cent to $39.42. Telstra lost 2.9 per cent to $5.62.
Just nine stocks recorded gains for the day, including vet chain Greencross, up 2.6 per cent, and aged care provider Japara, up 2.2 per cent.
